key_title: Key to the species of Deyeuxia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Poaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Mature lemma generally shorter than or subequal to glumes, occasional spikelets may have the lemma up to 0.5 mm longer than the glumes
Mature lemma distinctly and consistently exceeding glumes by 0.5 mm or more
Awn about as long as lemma or longer, and distinctly exceeding it
Awn much shorter than lemma, usually not or barely exceeding it (awns of some species are early-deciduous, check several spikelets in inflorescence or look for scar of awn)
Awn attached in lower one-third of lemma
Awn attached above lower one-third of lemma

Rachilla bristle plumose, about half as long to almost as long as lemma; leaf-blades stiffish, narrowly inrolled; sheaths usually reddish; inflorescence more or less cylindric but rarely dense; chiefly of alps and subalps
Rachilla bristle not produced; leaf-blades flat, sheaths pale; inflorescence usually dense, cylindric; widespread but rare in alps or subalps

Lemma with raised scabrous nerves; palea bulging at maturity to expose raised and scabrous nerves between lemma margins; callus hair length 0.3–0.5 mm; ratio of callus hair length to lemma length 15–20 %
Lemma surface uniform; palea hardly visible between lemma margins; callus hair length 0.5–1.5 mm; callus hair length to lemma ratio 15–40 %
Awn not twisted at base, recurved but not abruptly bent
Awn geniculate, twisted at base
Inflorescence loose, sometimes the branches held against the axis (usually when young), but not bearing spikelets to near their bases
Inflorescence more or less cylindric, panicle branches bearing spikelets almost to their bases
Spikelets 4–5.5 mm long; mature lemmas hardly plump, awned from about midway
Spikelets 3–4 mm long; mature lemmas plump, usually awned above midway
Rachilla bristle produced beyond callus; lemma not 4-toothed at apex (but sometimes shallowly cleft into 2 lobes)
Rachilla bristle not produced beyond callus; lemma shortly 4-toothed at apex
Spikelets strongly laterally compressed; lemmas acute or obtuse, shining and virtually smooth in the lower part, scabrous above; rachilla bristle to c. 1 mm long, not plumose

Spikelets not strongly laterally compressed; lemmas narrow-acuminate at apex, evenly scabrous; rachilla bristle plumose, about half as long as lemma; mostly in lowlands but at high-altitudes in the Grampians
Lemmas strongly 5-nerved and rather abruptly narrowed above midway; scabrous in lower part but virtually smooth between nerves; spikelets mostly c. 3.5 mm long; panicle typically 4 cm long or less
Lemmas indistinctly nerved, evenly tapered to apex; smooth or uniformly and very finely scabrous; spikelets mostly c. 5 mm long; panicle typically 5 cm long or more
Callus hairs up to one-third as long as lemma
Callus hairs (at least those arising laterally) from about half to three-quarters as long as lemma: montane to alpine grasses

Leaf-blades rather stiff, strongly inrolled and needle-pointed; inflorescence narrow, more or less cylindric; lemmas rather prominently 5–7-nerved; rare, apparently confined to rocky outcrops near Suggan Buggan
Leaf-blades flat or folded, not needle-pointed; lemmas indistinctly nerved; grasses of forests or higher alps
Inflorescence rather dense, cylindric, with branches bearing spikelets virtually to base; leaves rather rigid
Inflorescence loose, usually spreading, if contracted then branches not bearing spikelets to base; leaves rather lax, lacking a thickened apical point; forest grasses

Spikelets 3.5–4 mm long; lemmas acute; rachilla bristle c. 0.5 mm long; blades mostly flat, but apex keeled with a thickened, incurved point; leaves often tinged reddish; uncommon grass of higher alps
Spikelets 2–3.5 mm long; lemmas truncate; rachilla bristle not produced; leaves channelled throughout, not or rarely reddish; rare lowland grass
Awn attached about halfway along lemma
Awn attached in upper one-third or lemma

Plants with fine, wiry, much-branched culms; often climbing (to c. 2 m high); lemma awnless or with very fine awn less than 1 mm long, attached just below apex; rare and apparently confined to moist lowland forests in the far east
Plants typically tufted with unbranched culms; lemma awned (but awn may be deciduous)
Spikelets 2–2.5 (rarely to 3) mm long; lemmas smooth or minutely scabrous, membranous at least at upper margin
Spikelets 3–5 mm long; lemmas rather coarsely scabrous, firm throughout; typically of upland forests
Lemma minutely but distinctly scabrous, nerves not prominent; rachilla bristle c. 0.5 mm long, glabrous or sparsely hairy; lax, fine-leaved grass, usually in rainforest
Lemma smooth, or almost so, prominently 5-nerved; rachilla bristle absent; usually a more or less erect grass of dry forest
Awn geniculate, readily deciduous; lemma plump; glumes gaping
Awn straight or nearly so, not readily deciduous; lemma narrow; glumes hardly gaping
Awn always present, 0.8–2 mm long; leaves closely folded, stiff; rare, highalpine grass of stony or gravelly seepage areas
Awn usually absent from at least some lemmas in inflorescence, up to 0.8 mm long; leaves flat or almost filiform, not particularly stiff
Largest inflorescences 20 cm long or more, very loose, with widely spreading branches; loosely tufted grass of montane forests and swamp margins in Bonang-Bendoc area
Inflorescences not exceeding 18 cm long, narrowly contracted
Spikelets 2–3 mm long; culms to 20 cm high; occasional grass of wetter grasslands and heathlands throughout alps
Spikelets 3.8–5.5 mm long; culms 25 cm high or more; rare grass of sphagnum bogs on the Cobberas and Nunniong Plateau
Plants with fine, wiry, much-branched culms; often climbing (to c. 2 m high); awn absent or very fine and appressed to lemma; rare and apparently confined to moist lowland forests in the far east
Plants tufted with simple culms; never climbing
Panicle 12–30 cm long, often nodding, branches neither stiff nor widely spreading; glumes acute, scabrous-pubescent along the length of the keel
Panicle to 8 cm long, with stiff, widely spreading branches at maturity; glumes obtuse, smooth or minutely scabrous along keel near tip
Callus glabrous
Callus hairy
